post_info.post_title: The effects of light-speed travel on car headlights

Love Never Dies

Question:
 
 If you are in a car, traveling at the speed of light, and you turn the headlights on....
 
 What happens?
 
 emoticon_frazzled

 Nothing happens.
 
 If you are traveling at the speed of light you are frozen in time.
 
 You can not reach out and turn on the lights.
 
 You enter light speed at the same moment you depart from it.
 
 For you there was no journey.
 
 This is called, time dilation.
 
 If you have questions, you may ask me.
Ooaman

Nothing happens.
 
 If you are traveling at the speed of light you are frozen in time.
 
 You can not reach out and turn on the lights.
 
 You enter light speed at the same moment you depart from it.
 
 For you there was no journey.
 
 This is called, time dilation.
 
 If you have questions, you may ask me.

 
 If a place is 10 light years away and you travel at the speed of light, it's bound to take 10 of some amount of time. The question is do you use that standard time or the metric time?
Love Never Dies

If a place is 10 light years away and you travel at the speed of light, it's bound to take 10 of some amount of time. The question is do you use that standard time or the metric time?

 No Einstein, at light speed time stops completely, period.
Ooaman

 Then why does it take upwards of 3 days for the Enterprise to get anywhere?emoticon_zzzz

 Because the enterprise exists outside of existing reality.

 You should never tell a Star Trek fan that the Enterprise doesn't really exist. You will get them fantasizing about setting their phasers to stung and firing them at your butt. Okay, well, some. Okay, probibly not really.

 I will need to look into that.
Kronus

But on a completely different subject; wouldn't it actually take forever for the people not going to the speed of light.

 
 First off, no object can go exactly the speed of light, it's impossible. But if something is 10 light years away, and you go at almost the speed of light, than it will take just over 10 years from the point of view of the people on the planet you left, but almost no time from your point of view. Looking out your front window it would look like the distance between you and your destination shrank to almost nothing as you approached .9999999 c.
Love Never Dies

First off, no object can go exactly the speed of light, it's impossible.

 This is incorrect.
sinjin

This is incorrect.
And remain an object? Please expand and give examples.
Love Never Dies

Light is a particle, it has mass.
 
 (Do not attempt to engage me in a semantic debate over the word object.)
Kronus

Light is a particle, it has mass.
 

 
 Light has no mass, and while it has a particle nature it is generally not helpful to think of it as just a particle. You may be thinking of relativistic mass, but Einstein's equations deal with rest mass, and the rest mass of a photon is 0.
 
 Here's a link talking about how photons are massless.
 
 http://math.ucr.edu/home/baez/physics/ParticleAndNuclear/photon_mass.html
Love Never Dies
